(CA IRB)

IAD File No. /Dossier: TA6-12600 TA6-12601 TA6-12602



1



REASONS FOR DECISION

Introduction [1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal, pursuant to subsection 63(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

(IRPA ) of T[REDACTED] (the principal appellant), his wife, [REDACTED] (the appellant) and E[REDACTED] (the minor appellant). They are appealing the de termination by the Minister’s Delegate, made on September 27, 2006, to issue a departure orders against them as a persons described in subsection 41(b) of IRPA

, because the Minister’s Delegate was satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, there were grounds to believe that the appellants were permanent residents who were inadmissible to Canada for failing to comp ly with the residency obligation contained in section 28 of IRPA

. [2] Specifically, the appellants had failed to reside in Canada for at least 730 days in the five- year period immediately after they became permanent residents, which was on March 27, 2003. The Minister’s Delegate was also not sati sfied, pursuant to section 28(2)(c) of IRPA

, that there were sufficient humanitarian and compassionate c onsiderations, taking into account the best interests of a child directly affected by the determination, to justify retention of permanent resident status and overcome the breach of the residency obligations. Background



[3] The principal appellant is 44 years old. He was born on July 18, 1963 in Kuwait, but he is a citizen of Lebanon. His wife is 38 years old and a citizen of Lebanon. His son, E[REDACTED], is 9 years old and a citizen of Le banon. There is a second son, [REDACTED], who is 7 years old. He is not an appellant in this appeal. [4] The family came to Canada as permanent re sidents on March 27, 2003. They left Canada and returned to Kuwait on April 12, 2003, when the principal appellant’s wife became ill in Canada with bronchial asthma. The principal appellant returned on March 2, 2006 and remained

challenging_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

TA4-09616

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the claimant) is a citizen of the People's Republic of China. He claims to have a well-founded fear of persecution at the hands of the Communist regime and in particular, the Public Security Bureau, by reason of his political opinion as a Falun Gong practitioner. In addition, he claims to be a person in need of protection because he would be subjected personally to a risk to his life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment or to a dange r of torture in the People's Republic of China. ALLEGATIONS: The claimant alleges that he started to practice Falun Gong in [REDACTED] 2003 in order to improve his health. The claimant stated that on [REDACTED], 2003, the Public Security Bureau raided his Falun Gong practice group. The claimant stated that he was not present at the time but was advised to go into hiding, which he did. The claimant indicated that he learned, while in hiding, that the Public Security Bureau had come to his home, looking to arrest him. The claimant made arrangements to leave the country and arrived in Canada on [REDACTED], 2003. DETERMINATION: I find that the claimant is neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.

2005 CanLII 60041 (CA IRB)

TA4-09616

2 ANALYSIS: Identity: The claimant’s oral testimony, the supporting documentation

1 filed and the RCMP report

2 establish his identity as a national of the People's Republic of China. I find that the Public Security Bureau is not, nor has ever been, interested in arresting the claimant. The claimant maintained that the Public Security Bureau went to his home on more than one occasion, looking to arrest him. The claimant stated that he left the People's Republic of China with his own genuine passport via the Beijing Airport. It was put to the claimant that the country documentation

3 indicates that there are a number of security checks at the Beijing Airpor t and that there is a computer system to check names. The claima...

challenging_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RPD File No. :

[1] [REDACTED], the principal claimant (PC), is a citizen of the Republic of Haiti (Haiti) who seeks refugee protection pursu ant to subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

1 (IRPA). The claim of her daughter, [REDACTED], the minor claimant, was joined pursuant to Rule 49.1.

2 The panel appointed the XX as the Designated Representative (DR) of the minor claimant. Allegations [2] The PC alleges that she joined the polit ical party Organisation du Peuple en Lutte (OPL). She alleges that on [REDACTED] 1997, a bu llet entered her home, which prompted her to go into hiding. She travelled with her daught er to the USA in [REDACTED] 1997. She claims to have made an asylum claim which was late r refused. She made a claim for protection in Canada in [REDACTED] 2007. She claims a well -founded fear of persecution for reason of her political opinion and her membership in a particular social group, namely her gender. [3] The minor claimant has French nationalit y by virtue of her birth at [REDACTED] [REDACTED]. The PC did not advance any evidence of perse cution or personalized risk for the minor claimant in her country of nationality. Issues and Determination [4] The panel finds that the claimants are neither Convention refugees, nor are they persons in need of protection. In reaching this decision, the panel considered the Chairperson’s Guidelines on Women Refugee Claimants Fearing Gender-Related Persecution.

3 The determinative issues were the credi bility of the claimant, the subjective fear and the personalized risk. The panel’s reasons are as follows:



1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2 Refugee Protection Division Rules , SOR/2002-228 11 June 2002.

3 Guidelines on Women Refugee Claimants Fear ing Gender-Related Persecution: Guidelines Issued by the Chairperson pursuant to section 65(3) of the Immigration Act, Immigration and Refugee Board, Ottawa, Canada, November 25, 1996, as cont...

challenging_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

[1] The [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ,

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , citizens of the Slovak Republic, seek refugee

protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refu gee Protection Act1

(IRPA). The claimants’ identities have been established through identity documents filed in

evidence.2

DESIGNATIVE REPRESENTATIVE

[2] [REDACTED] , lawyer, Law Offices of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , acted as Designated Represtenative

for the claimants who wer e all minors.

[3] Social Worker, [REDACTED] , from the Children’s Aid Society, was in attendance.

ALLEGATIONS

[4] The following is a summary of the claimants’ allegations:

[5] The claimants have not lived with their parents for over a year. Presently they reside with

two different foster families. They are wards of the state in the care of the Children’s Aid Society.

[6] They alleged that they have been physically abused by their parents through neglect and

unwillingness to provide the basic necessities of life. They alleged that their mother is lazy and

required that they do most of the housework. She does not care about them, she does not cook and

clean the house and she does not care if they go to school or not. Their father repeatedly hit them

even for the simplest of thi ngs. They alleged that their father is usually drunk and physically and

verbally abusive. While they have always been physically and verbally abused even in their

country, it has gotten worse here in Canada.

[7] The claimants alleged that in their country they do not give jobs to Roma, and when their

father did work he would come home most often drunk and he and their mother would get into

fights. The alleged that their parents would not be able to take care of them if they return to their

country.



1 As enacted by S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2 Exhibit R/A -2, Information rec...

TB8 -05950 / TB8 -05951





RAD.25.02 ( September 18 , 2018)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION



INTRODUCTION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “ Principal Appellant”) is a citizen of Venezuela . [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “Female Appellant”) is a citizen of both Venezuela and Iran. [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “Minor Appellant”) is a citizen of both Venezuela and the United

States (US). They are appealing a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying

their claim s for refugee protection.

[2] The Principal Appellant’s claim was refused on the grou nds that he was found not

credible. The Female and Minor Appellants were found not to be refugees or persons in need of

protection as they had not established claims against Iran or the US respectively.

[3] The Principal Appellant was appointed as the Designat ed Representative (DR) for the

Minor Appellant at the RPD.

DETERMINATION S

[4] The Principal Appellant’s appeal is allowed. The Female and Minor Appellants’ appeals

are dismissed.

BACKGROUND

[5] The Principal Appellant alleges that he was a senior government civil servant with an 18 -

year career in Venezuela. The Principal Appellant began to voice disagreement with his

superiors about the actions of the government, including forcing his workers to attend pro -

government rallies, and the firings of workers who expresse d dissent with the government.

[6] The Principal Appellant alleges that he and his family were visited by the Bolivarian

National Intelligence Service (SEBIN), collectivos and other state agents as a result of his

RAD File / Dossier de la SAR : VB9 -07031 / VB9 -07032

VB9 -07033 / VB9 -07034 / VB9 -07035





RAD.25.02 (January, 2020)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION



OVERVIEW



[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal Appellant ), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal

Appellant’s Spouse ), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal Appellant’s Son ), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] (Female Appellant ) and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Female Appellant’s Son ) appeal a

decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) rejecting their claims for refugee protection.

They request that the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) set aside the RPD ’s decision and find that

the Appellants are Convention1 refugees or persons in need of protection or in the alternative that

the RAD set aside the RPD decision and refer the matter back to the RPD for reconsideration

before another Panel.



DETERMINATION OF THE APPEAL



[2] Pursuant to section 111(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA ),2 the

Panel confirms the determination of the RPD, namely, that the Appellants are neither Convention

refugees pursuant to section 96 of the IRPA nor are they persons in need of protection pursuant

to section 97 of the IRPA .



BACKGROUND



[3] The Principal Appellant and the Principal Appellant’s Spouse are citizens of Colombia.

They were also permanent residents of Chile. The Principal Appellant’s Son is a citizen of Chile.

The Principal Appellants was appointed as the Designated Representative of his son at the RPD.

The Panel has recognized the Principal Appellant as the Designated Representative of his son for

the purpose of this appeal.



[4] The Female Appellant and the Female Appellant’s Son are both citizens of Colombia.

The Female Appellant was appointed as the Designated Representative of her son at the RPD

VB9 -06107 / VB9 -06108





RAD.25.02 ( January , 20 20)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION



OVERVIEW



[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal Appellant) , and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Associate Appellant) , and

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Minor Appellant) , (collectively the Appellants), appeal a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (RPD), dated July 19, 2019, rejecting their claims for refugee

protection on the grounds of an Internal Flight Alte rnative (IFA) in Abuja, Ibadan or Port

Harcourt. The Principal Appellant was the Designated Representative for the Minor Appellant in

this proceeding. I have conducted an independent analysis of all the evidence concerned, and

have determined the Appellant s are not Convention1 Refugees or persons in need of protection .



BACKGROUND



[2] The Principal Appellant and the Associate Appellant both completed [REDACTED] school in

Ukraine, and the Associate Appellant has worked as a [REDACTED] in Nigeria. The Principal

Appellant also studied [REDACTED] in Dubai and the Associate Appellant lived for some time in South

Korea. The Associate Appellant’s father was a very wealthy man who comes from a large,

polygamous family in Nigeria. He died suddenly, leaving investments in South Korea, the United

States (US) , and Nigeria and several properties and businesses in Nigeria, but no will. The

Associate Appellant has a half -brother, [REDACTED] , who has a different mother, and who is

aggrieved because of his alleged inferior treatment by the family and also believes that, as he is

the oldest son, he is entitled to control his late father’s estate. Additionally, the extended family

of the Associate Appellant disliked her mother because she is not from their tribe and is

originally from Ghana. The Associate Appellant has been harassed, assaulted and threatened. In

[REDACTED] 2015, the [REDACTED] moved from Benin City to Abuja and stayed with the Prin...

RAD File / Dossier de la SAR : TB9 -08462

TB9 -08463 / TB9 -08464





RAD.25.02 ( January , 20 20)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION



OVERVIEW



[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal Appellant ), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

(Principal Appellant’s Daughter ) and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (Principal Appellant’s Son ) are

appealing a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (R PD) rejecting their claims for refugee

protection. T hey request that the Refugee Appeal Division (R AD) set aside the RPD's decision

under section 111(1)(b) and find that they are Convention1 refugees or perso ns in need of

protection.



DETERMINATION OF THE APPEAL



[2] Pursuant to section 111(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA ),2 the

Panel sets aside the determination of the RPD and refers the matter back to the RPD for re -

determination with respect to the principal appellant . The panel confirms the decision of the

RPD with respect to the principal appellant’s daughter and son under Section 111(1)(a) of the

IRPA. The panel finds that the minor appellants are not Convention refugees or persons in need

of protection.



BACKGROU ND



[3] The Principal Appellant is a citizen of Venezuela and Lebanon. T he Principal Appellant’s

Daughter a nd Son are citizens of the United States . The Principal Appellant was a [REDACTED] in

Venezuela. I n 2012 he travel led to Turkey and Germany where he met with the Minister of Food

and Industry as well as [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , the present leader of Venezuela. T he Principal Appellant

stated that he exchanged phone numbers with the individuals. W hen he returned to Venezuela, he

was con tacted by these individuals and asked to attend a meeting in Caracas.

RPD File / Dossier de la SPR : TB7 -22488

TB7 -22521 / TB7 -22532



1

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , (the principal claimant), [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , (the female

claimant), and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , (minor claimant), seek protection in Canada pursuant to

sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1 They allege a

well -founded fear of persecution in Pakistan from Tehrik -i-Taliban.

[2] Pursuant to Rule 55(1) of the Refugee Protection Division Rules,2 these claims have been

joined. The Refugee Protection Division (the RPD) has designated [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] the

representative for the minor claimant, pursuant to IRPA section 167(2).

ALLEGATIONS

[3] The claimants allege that they meet the definition of Convention refugee, in that they are

“persons who by reason of a well -founded fear of persecution for reasons of their nationality and

membership in a particular social group are outside their country of nationality and are unable,

by reason of that fear, or are unwilling to avail themselves of the protection of that county”,

namely Pakistan. In the alternative, they allege they are persons in need of protection. Their fear

stems from the attempts of Tehrik -i-Taliban (Taliban) to recruit the principal claimant. A

summary of their allegations f ollows:

 The principal claimant comes from [REDACTED] or [REDACTED] , a small village in

[REDACTED] , which is in the Khyber -Pakhtunkhwa (KP) region of Pakistan.

 In [REDACTED] 2008, the Taliban attempted to recruit him into its ranks. He told

them he was not interested, but they i nsisted that he meet with them at a

certain “checkpoint”. When he failed to show up, three men went to the

family home to look for him. His father advised him to go into hiding,

which he did. He principal claimant went to the village of [REDACTED] , where

he foun d work as a [REDACTED] . He lost his job when men came ...

RAD File / Dossier de la SAR : VB8 -03817



RAD.25.02 ( April 04, 201 9)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION



INTRODUCTION



[1] The Appellant Minister appeals a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD),

dated June 22, 2018 , accepting the claim for refugee protection of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

(the Respondent ) who is a citizen of Honduras .



[2] The RAD dismisses the appeal and confirm s the decision of the RPD that the A ppellant is

a person in need of protection, pursuant to section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection

Act (IRPA).1



[3] The determinative issues in this appeal are whether the RPD erred in its credibility

assessment and section 97 analysis regarding risk.



OVERVIEW OF APPEAL



[4] The Respondent is a 45 -year -old female from Honduras. The Respondent and her family

have been targeted by a criminal gang in Honduras over a several year period. She fears that if

she returns to her country, she will be again extorted by criminal gangs and that she will be

perceived as someone who has money or could get money. Since she will not be able to make

extortion payments she fears that she will be killed or her children will be kidnapped to force her

to make payments as has occurred with at least one family member in the past.



The RPD Finding



[5] The RPD found the Respondent to be a credible witness who testified in a straightforward

manner. The RPD also found that the Respondent and her fa mily had been targeted over a long

period of time by a criminal gang and that her half -brother was murdered by the gang as a

message to the family in regard to the payment of an extortion or war tax. The RPD found the

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (a.k.a. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , the principal Appellant) and her

minor daughters [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (a.k.a. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ) and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (a.k.a. [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] ), the minor Appellants , citizens of Nigeria, appeal a decision of the Refugee

Protection Division (RPD) denying their claims for refugee protection. The principal Appellant

has agreed to act as the D esignated Representative for her minor daughters with respect to thei r

claims. They have not submitted any new evidence in support of their claims but have requested

an oral hearing. The Appellants request that the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) set aside the

determination of the RPD and find that they are Convention refugee s or persons in need of

protection or, in the alternative, to refer the matter back to the RPD.

DETERMINATION

[2] Pursuant to sub section 111(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA),

the RAD refers the principal Appellant’s claim back to the RPD for re -determination. The

principal Appellant’s appeal is allowed.

[3] Pursuant to sub section 11 1(1)(a) of the IRPA, the RAD confirms the determination of the

RPD regarding the minor Appellant s’ claims. These appeals are dismissed.

BACKGROUND

[4] The principal Appellant alleged before the RPD that she fears for her safety on the basis of

her sexual orientation if she has to return to her home country of Nigeria. She claims that she is a

bisexual woman. She also alleges that her childr en may be impacted as a result by possibly being

removed from her custody, and also alleges that there is a possibility that she and/or her children

may be subject to female genital mutilation (FGM) if they return to Nigeria.

[5] The Appellant reports that she is a bisexual wom an and that she has had a number of

(CA IRB)

RAD File / Dossier de la SAR : TB9 -34721

TB9 -34722 / TB9 -34723 / TB9 -34724



RAD.25.02 ( January , 20 20)

Disponible en français 2

REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW

[1] The Appellants are [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (“the Principal Appellant ”), his wife

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (“Ms. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ”), their minor son [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] (“[REDACTED] ”), and their minor daughter [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

(“[REDACTED] ”). The Principal Appellant, Ms. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and [REDACTED] are Nigerian

citizens. [REDACTED] was born in the United States and is therefore an American citizen. The

Appellants fear political persecution in Nigeria due to the Principal Appellant’s involvement i n

the All Progressives Congress (“APC”) . The Appellants fear that members of the People’ s

Democratic Party (“PDP”) will seek to harm them . The Refugee Protection Division (“RPD”)

rejected the Appella nts’ claims . The RPD identified problems with the credibility of the Principal

Appellant’s testimony. The panel appeared to accept the facts around the Principal Appellant’s

political activities , but it determined that there was a viable internal flight alternative (“IFA”) in

Abuja. The Appellants dispute this decision and provide new evidence that addresses the RPD’s

findings.

[2] The result of this appeal is a split decision . A claim against the United Sta tes was not

advanced for [REDACTED] at the RPD, nor have the Appellants disputed the RPD’s reasons for

rejecting her claim. No risks have been identified for [REDACTED] in the United States that would

entitle her to refugee protection . The Refugee Appeal Division (“RAD”) therefore a gree s with

the RPD’s reasons for rejecting her claim. Pursuant to paragraph 111(1)( a) of the Immigration

and Refugee Protection Act (“IRPA”), the appeal in regard to [REDACTED] claim is dismissed.

(CA IRB)

[1] The claimants state that they are citizens of Swaziland and claim refugee protection in

accordance with sections 96 to 99 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act . [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] is also a citizen of South Africa.

[2] The claimants constitute a family. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] is the mother of two minor

claimants, [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] age [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] age [REDACTED] as well as her adult son , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] age [REDACTED] X. The ir

claims were joined with that of a nephew, [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] age [REDACTED] [REDACTED] . The

adult female claimant was designated as the representative of the two minor claimant s on [REDACTED]

[REDACTED] [REDACTED] 2012 in accordance with subsection 167(2) of the Immigration and Refugee

Protection Act .

[3] Identity has been established by means of Swaziland passports.

DETERMINATION

[4] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] is a Convention refugee. The other four claimants are neither

Convention refugees nor persons in need of protection.

FINDINGS OF FACT

[5] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] husband and the father of the two minor claimants, [REDACTED] and

[REDACTED] , is [REDACTED] was a member of the People ’s United Democratic Movement

(PUDEMO ). Authorities attempted to arrest him after a bridge was bombed in [REDACTED] 2009, but

were unable to do so because he fled to South Africa. In their attempt to locate him, police began

to harass and question the claimants. [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] was detained for questioning on a

number of occasions and assaulted. In [REDACTED] or [REDACTED] 2010 her house was also searched and

she was again taken in for questioning. After release she went to live with her sister at [REDACTED] in

[REDACTED] 2010. However, the police visited her there and asked her again about her husband. She

challenging_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI: TB5 -08779

TB5 -08781

Client ID No. / No ID client: 5277 -0849

5277 -0809





ORAL REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal s of [REDACTED] and

[REDACTED] (the appellants) , who appeal ed from a determin ation that they breached the

residency obligation.

ISSUE

[2] The five -year period under consideration is from July 5, 2010 to July 5, 2015. The parties

agreed that the appellants were in the country for only 249 days during the five -year period. This

is only 34 percent compliance. The visa officer’s determination is legally valid . T he appellants

are asking f or special relief on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds.

HUMANITARIAN AND COMPASSIONATE GROUNDS

[3] I heard testimony from the appellant , Mr. [REDACTED] . Based on the testimony, the Minister’s

counsel recommended the appeal s be allowed for the reasons that follows .

[4] Mr. [REDACTED] and his wife landed in July , 2009. We heard testimony that the appellants

returned to Iran because Mr. [REDACTED] had not yet retired from his job , and their second son was in

university in Iran at the time . Given the ties they stil l had to Iran, the appellants return ed in order

to wind up their affairs , and to prepare for a late r stage of their life and retirement. Such is the

reason for their departure from Canada .

[5] The reason the appellants extended their stay abroad was because Mr. [REDACTED] ’s father

had heart problems in 2011 , and suffered from a stroke . Since Mr. [REDACTED] was a medical doctor,

he remained in Iran to take care of his father , as he felt that he was in the best position to do so ,

given his training as a medical doctor.

[6] Mr. [REDACTED] has a brother and three sisters in Teheran ; since his father is now recovered,

he testified that his siblings are able to assume the responsibility of the care of their father. The

challenging_cases.case_text:
(CA IRB)

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :





REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Appellant) is a citizen of Saint Lucia. She appeals a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying her claim for refugee protection. The Appellant asks

the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) to set aside the decision of the RPD, and find the Appellant

to be a Convention refugee, or in the alternative, refer the claim back to the RPD for

redetermination. The Appellant asks for a hearing to deal with the documentation presented in the

Memorandum of Appeal. No new evidence was presented in the Me morandum of Appeal.

DETERMINATION

[2] Pursuant to ss. 111(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), the RAD

confirms the determination of the RPD and dismisses the appeal.

Background

[3] The Appellant was raised by her stepmother, and does not ha ve any knowledge of her

biological mother. The Appellant discovered during her teenage years that she was more attracted

to girls than boys. As a result of the homophobic attitudes in Saint Lucia, the [REDACTED] became

withdrawn and unhappy emotionally. The Appellant discovered a girl in the school who felt the

same way, and began a nonsexual relationship. After the relationship became more physical, they

were discovered by other students who made life a torment at school. Both she and her friend

dropped out of secondary school in [REDACTED] 1997. The Appellant ’s father and stepmother tried to

convince her to go back to school in another location, but she refused, and ran away from home.

While living on the streets, a man befriended her, took her into his home, and she became

sexually active with him. After the birth of a daughter on [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , 2000, the relationship

ended, but she continued to live with this man in a nonsexual relationship, all the time seeing her

girlfriend from high school. At the Appellant ’s wor kplace, she and her girlfriend were discovered

em...

Reasons for Decision

Introduction [1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeals of Rajes[REDACTED] (the principal appellant), his wife, Jayshr[REDACTED], and his sons, Xi[REDACTED] and A[REDACTED], pursuant to subsection 63(3) of the Immigration and

as permanent residents who are inadmissible to Canada for failing to comply with conditions imposed under the former Immigration Regulations

(CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI: Client ID No. / N

o ID client: 3743-2055 3993-3698 3743-2055

2



2010 CanLII 95253 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI: Client ID No. / N

o ID client: 3743-2055 3993-3698 3743-2055

1



Reasons for Decision

Introduction and Issue [1] These are three appeals pursu ant to section 63(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

1 (IRPA) of departure orders based on IRPA section 41(b) made against each of the three appellants. The appellants are a mother

2 (“appellant mother”) and her two daughters ([REDACTED],

3 “eldest appellant daughter”; and [REDACTED] “youngest appellant daughter”). [2] The appellants do not contest the validity of the departure orders and the issue is whether the appellants have proven that there are gr ounds to warrant special relief, pursuant to IRPA section 67(c). Decision [3] Having considered the evidence and submissi ons, and especially the submissions of the respondent, the panel finds that the departure orders are valid in law. The panel finds that the three appellants have proven on a balance of pr obabilities that their appeals warrant special relief. The three appeals are allowed.



1 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27.

2 TA8-18674.

3 TA8-18702.

4 TA8-18703.

2010 CanLII 95253 (CA IRB)

IAD File No. / No de dossier de la SAI: Client ID No. / N

o ID client: 3743-2055 3993-3698 3743-2055

2

Background [4] The Immigration Division held an admissibility hearing in September 2008

5 and issued a departure order against each appellant.

6 The departure orders were based on non-compliance with the entrepreneurial class entry conditions of the husband/father permanent resident (who is not a party to this appeal).

7 The three appellants appeal from those orders.8 [5] With the agreement of the appellants and respondent, the appeals of the three appellants were dealt with at the same hearing, with all evidence applying to each appeal, and one ...
